prompt.p: A 43-year-old man presents with tiredness, headaches, sweats and a change in his vision. His wife states that his clothes do not fit him any more. The man concerned is shown in the figure.
What investigation would be most appropriate for this patient?
Swartz, Textbook of Physical Diagnosis: History and Examination , 6 th edn.

modalFeedback.p: Option C (Serum insulin growth factor-1) is Correct. Acromegaly is usually due to a pituitary adenoma. Growth hormone excess will cause an increase in insulin growth factor-1. It is a stimulator of cell proliferation and growth. The figure shows that this patient has an enlarged mandible and nose, and prominent supraorbital ridge.
[Fig. reproduced from Swartz, Textbook of Physical Diagnosis: History and Examination , 6 th edn., 2009, with permission from Elsevier. Fig. 1.2 Acromegaly]

Option A (24-hour urinary cortisol) is Incorrect. This is used to detect excess cortisol in Cushing's syndrome. Cushing's can cause truncal obesity and, if due to a pituitary adenoma, could cause visual field changes.

Option B (Random urinary glucose) is Incorrect. Glycosuria is present in diabetes mellitus. It causes an osmotic diuresis leading to polyuria and polydipsia, ultimately causing weight loss due to dehydration and a tissue catabolism (fat/muscle) due to insulin deficiency.

Option D (Short synacthen test) is Incorrect. This is used in Addison's disease. After administration it causes plasma cortisol levels to rise in a normal individual. It does not cause coarse facial features.

Option E (Thyroid function test) is Incorrect. This is used to measure thyroid function. Tiredness would occur in hypothyroidism and sweating in hyperthyroidism. It does not cause coarse facial features.
